div1.head: Report: Laboratory Findings, Case of G. A. Bradinelli, by Hideyo Noguchi, May 24, 1923
div1.p:
Laboratory Findings, Case of G. A. Bradinelli.
Died November 11, 1922. Tissues submitted by Dr. A. Connal,
Medical Research Institute,
Yaba, West Africa.

The changes in the liver are rather mild. With this
type of degeneration and necrosis, the disease might be
either infectious jaundice or yellow fever; it was apprently
a “border-line” case. Judging from the clinical record,
I think it was either yellow fever or a very severe case of
infectious jaundice. The histological appearance of the
organs would indicate infectious jaundice rather than
yellow fever.

Sections of tissue stained by Levaditi's silver
impregnation method showed no leptospiras.
